Shawn Loren KELLOGG Shawn was born November 4, 1974 in Nairobi, Kenya, to Richard and Peggy Kellogg. He died April 2, 2011 at Providence Hospital, Everett. Shawn grew up in the sunshine of Kisumu, Kenya, and moved to the Seattle area with his family when he was 5½ years old. He attended North Seattle Christian School, Shoreline Community College, and Northwest University. He rowed on the Green Lake Crew, and enjoyed it immensely. Shawn served in Youth With A Mission in Switzerland and Bolivia. He worked at all kinds of jobs, and was good at whatever he did. Shawn enjoyed skiing, snowboarding, motorcycling, SCUBA diving, hiking and camping, and hanging out with friends. He fished in Alaska out of Dutch Harbor. Shawn had plenty of struggles in life, and always thought he would be able to overcome them. Now his struggles are over. He loved Jesus, and wanted to be used of God. Shawn was a lover of people, and people enjoyed Shawn. He was great fun to be with and talk to. Shawn is survived by his parents; his brother, Chad; his grandmother, Leona Cettolin; his aunts, Kathryn Kellogg, Debbie Kellogg, Paulette Stickland, and Sheryl Love; his uncles, Brent Kellogg, Bill Stickland, and Don Stickland. A memorial service will be held at 12:00 noon, Thursday, April 7 at The Westside Church, 7758 Earl Avenue NW, Seattle, WA 98177. Memorial gifts may be made to New Heart Place, care of Westgate Chapel, 22901 Edmonds Way, Edmonds, WA 98020.

WAYNESBORO, Ga.- Mrs. Virginia Wilson Rowland, 78, wife of the late Mr. T. R. (Buddy) Rowland, entered into rest February 23, 2004 at the Brentwood Terrace, Waynesboro. Mrs. Rowland was a homemaker and native of Doraville, Ga. and spent most of her adult life in Vidette, Ga. She was a member of the Bethel Associated Reformed Presbyterian Church of Vidette. A charter member of White Columns Women's Club, Waynesboro, Ladies Shrine Auxiliary and the Sarah Pressley Missionary Circle. Funeral services will be held 11 a.m. Wednesday, February 25, 2004 at the Bethel ARP Church with Dr. Roy Beckham officiating with interment following at Rose Dhu Cemetery, Vidette. Survivors include one son, Tommy Rowland, Vidette; two daughters, Susan R. Coursey, Waynesboro and Pat R. Smith of Hephzibah. Also survived by seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Pallbearers will be Dr. Jimmy Alexander, Lloyd Martin, J.S. Thomas, Bill Stallsmith, Dr. B. Lamar Murray, Ja mes Hollingsworth, Manton Horton, Jr. and Frank Agerton. Family will receive friends Tuesday, February 24, 2004 from 7 to 9 p.m. at the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to the Bethel ARP Church, 7256 Hwy. 24, West, Louisville, Ga. 30434. Services entrusted to DeLoach-Kennedy Funeral Home, 842 Liberty Street, Waynesboro, Ga. 706-554-3531. Sign the guestbook at AugustaChronicle.com

JIM FALLS -- Darrell J. "Dude" Felmlee, 71, of 13671 195th St., Jim Falls, town of Anson, died Monday, July 5, 2004, at his residence with St. Joseph's Hospice. He was born Sept. 26, 1932, in Jim Falls, the son of John S. and Bessee (Sherman) Felmlee. He worked for Jim Falls Dairy for 40 years and was a supervisor on the Jim Falls town board. He married Neomi Fox on Aug. 13, 1957, at Sacred Heart Church, Jim Falls. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus Jean Brunet Council #4948 and Sacred Heart Church, Jim Falls where he was very active in his church. He is survived by: his wife, Neomi; three brothers, George (Wilma) of Billings, Mont., Glen (Wanda) of Cokato, Minn., and Bill (Joan) of Jim Falls; one sister, Lorraine Heidtke of Chippewa Falls; and several nieces and nephews and other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by: his parents; one brother, John Felmlee; and one sister, Virginia Felmlee. Funeral services will be held at 10:30 a.m. Thursday, July 8 at Sacred Heart Church, Jim Falls. Interment will be in Copp Cemetery, town of Anson. Friends may call from 4 to 8 p.m. Wednesday, July 7 and until 9:30 a.m. Thursday at the Horan Funeral Home, Chippewa Falls. There will be a Christian Vigil Service at 4:30 p.m. Wednesday at the funeral home.

SOUTHINGTON - Ingrid Gale, 88 of Meriden Ave., died Saturday, Jan. 26, 2008, at the HCC @ Bradley Memorial. She was the beloved wife of Albert Gale.   Born Aug.19, 1919 in Waterbury, a daughter of the late Charles and Valborg (Svenning) Green. Ingrid retired from Town Dry Cleaners and was also a well known Silk Finisher in the area. She was a member of St. Paul Episcopal Church and the Southington Calendar House.   Besides her husband, she is survived by three children, Nancy Almquist and her husband, Richard Sr. of Southington, Thomas Gale Sr. and his wife, Michele of Southington and Barbara Gale of Kensington; four grandchildren, Karen Perry and her husband, Bo, Richard Almquist Jr., Melanie Deal and her husband, Brian and Thomas Gale Jr. and his wife, Melissa; four great-grandchildren, Thomas and Olivia Deal, Isabella and Annelise Gale. She was predeceased by a son-in-law, Gerald Thibeault.   The funeral will be held on Tuesday, Jan. 29, 10 a.m. at St. Paul Episcopal Church, 145 Main St., Southington. Burial will follow in St. Thomas Cemetery. Calling hours will be Monday from 4 to 7 p.m. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Southington Calendar House Memorial Fund, 388 Pleasant St., Southington, CT 06489. For online condolences and directions please visit, www.dellavecchiafh.com.

Cloyd Allen Bookout, 72, of 109 Richfield Terrace, husband of Martha Wiley Bookout, died Tuesday, June 10, 2008, at Greenville Memorial Medical Center. Born in Gastonia, N.C., he was the son of the late Reverend Leslie Edward and Creola Pernell Coffey Bookout. Mr. Bookout was a Broadcaster with WPTF, Raleigh, N.C.; WAME and WSOC in Charlotte, N.C.; WESC, WSSL, and WSPA TV in the upstate. He was a member of Brushy Creek Baptist Church, where he was a deacon and teacher. He formerly served as music director for Beulah Baptist Church, Fountain Inn; Tanglewood Baptist Church, Greenville; Brushy Creek Baptist Church, Taylors; and Victory Baptist Church, Gastonia, N.C. Surviving, in addition to his wife, are two sons, SFC Edward Bookout and his wife, Emily, of Vicenza, Italy and David Bookout and his wife, Andrea, of Greenville; and three grandsons, Ethan, Dawson and Joseph Bookout. Memorials may be made to the Mission Projects of Brushy Creek Baptist Church, 4999 Old Spartanburg Road, Taylors, SC 29687. Visitation will be held Friday, June 13, 2008, from 6 to 8 p.m. at Thomas McAfee Funeral Home, Downtown. The funeral service will be held Saturday, June 14, 2008, at 11 a.m. at Brushy Creek Baptist Church. Burial will follow in Graceland East Memorial Park. The family will be at the residence.Condolences may be sent to the family by visiting www.thomasmcafee.com

Donald F. Smith Sr., 69, of Elmhurst Twp., died Wednesday at home after a courageous battle with lung cancer. His wife of 46 years is the former Judith Elaine Flesch, originally from Scranton.Don was born in his family's Elmhurst Twp. home on Nov. 23, 1940, and was the oldest son of the late Franklin Z. and Wilma Yeager Smith. Don graduated from Scranton Central High School in 1957 and Broome Technical Community College. Before retirement, he was an engineer with General Electric and managed Bard Electronics. He also served as Elmhurst Twp. tax collector for many years.Don was a woodworking and metalworking craftsman, designing and creating countless projects for himself and others, including most prominently making his own violins. He enjoyed bluegrass music and the camaraderie of his friends when playing the fiddle or shooting pool.Until recently, he was an avid fisherman and golfer. He enjoyed going out to eat with his wife and friends and spending time with his family, especially his two grandchildren. Don also liked to work outdoors, planting flowers, picking blueberries and feeding the deer in his yard.Don was active in community organizations, serving as treasurer of First Presbyterian Church for many years, was a member and treasurer of Elmhurst/Roaring Brook Volunteer Fire Company, past master of Moscow Masonic Lodge and a member of Moscow Sportsman's Club.Don was a loving and caring husband, father and grandfather who will be greatly missed by all who knew him.The family wishes to thank Mercy Hospice for its compassionate care of Don for these last weeks.Also surviving are two sons, Donald F. Smith Jr., Pittsburgh; and Douglas A. Smith; a daughter-in-law, Amy Smith; and two grandchildren, Dayle Lynn Smith and Doug Smith Jr., all of Mount Cobb; three brothers, Kenneth and wife, Elyse, Somers, N.Y.; Robert and wife, Patricia, Haines City, Fla.; and Frank and wife, Cathy, Cortland, N.Y.; two aunts, Alice Smith, Beacon, N.Y.; and Evelyn Searing, Scranton; several nieces and nephews.Don wished that his body be donated to Commonwealth Medical College, Scranton, supporting his lifelong interest in science.There will be no visitation, but a memorial service will be May 22 at 11 a.m. in First Presbyterian Church of Elmhurst.In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to either First Presbyterian Church of Elmhurst or the American Cancer Society.Arrangements by Snowdon Funeral Home Inc., Moscow.

POLITANO Al Politano, age 80, of Milford, a self-employed salesman, died on Sunday, November 6, 2005, at the West Haven Veterans Hospital. Survivors include a daughter, Eileen Klein of Milford; a son, Richard Politano of Ansonia; five grandchildren, Jessica Klein, April Kandrach, Rikki, Sara and Zachary Politano; four great-grandchildren, Joey, Miranda, Trevanna and Risten; and several nieces and nephews. Interment will follow in Kings Highway Cemetery, Milford. Friends may call on Wednesday (TODAY) from 4 to 8 p.m. To light a virtual candle, visit us at www.abriola.com.

Viola Janette Till, 81, died on March 21, 2008, from a long illness at her home in Klamath Falls with her daughter Debra Till at her bedside.  At her request, there will be no services.  Viola was born on April 26, 1926, in Fort William, Ontario, Canada, to David Ross and Jane Cecilia Hayes.  She went to school in Rock Island, Ill.  On April 22, 1946, Viola married Frank H. Till Jr.  She enjoyed fishing, camping, spending time with her family and friends, cooking and entertaining groups of friends, and being with her cats.  Viola is survived by her daughter and caregiver Debra Till, Klamath Falls, Ore.; two sons Rodney Till and his wife Kathy and grandson Michael, all Oxford, Ala., and Dennis Till, San Francisco, Calif.; one brother Victor Ross in Iowa; plus nieces and nephews.  Viola also has left behind a lot of special friends who will miss her dearly: Gerald Hartley, James Auld, Mary Macher and her father Frank Benac and Georgianna Garrison, and all the wonderful people of Klamath Hospice.  She was preceded in death by her parents, three sisters, a son, a baby daughter and a nephew.  "I want to thank Klamath Hospice for the wonderful job they did for Viola Till!" Debra, with much Love!  Davenport's Chapel of the Good Shepherd, directors, is in charge of the arrangements.

PEEBLES, Stuart A. Stuart A. Peebles passed away March 10, 2017, in Dunwoody, following an extended illness. He was born April 2, 1926, in Syracuse, NY, and is survived by his wife Sallie Moore Peebles of Dunwoody; two sons David Peebles (Sheila Lemke) of Syracuse and Andrew Peebles (Genelle) of Skaneateles, NY; and daughter Susan McLaughlin (David) of Seneca, S.C. as well as six grandchildren; and six great grandchildren; nephew Chuck Sandford of Atlanta and niece Priscilla Worral of Skaneateles, NY. Mr. Peebles was a graduate of Syracuse University with a degree in Civil Engineering and a master's degree in Business Accounting. He was associated with Allied Chemical Co. in Syracuse and New York City until 1970. From 1971 until 1999, he was president and principal owner of the Tidwell Office Supply Company in downtown Atlanta. He headed the Fairlie Poplar Task Force and was instrumental in restoration of the area. He was a member of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, the Atlanta Convention Bureau and Central Atlanta Progress. He was a member of the Peachtree Kiwanis Club where he served as president and lieutenant governor of Division 1. He was a member of the Atlanta Chapter of the Financial Executives Institute where he served as president. He and his wife lived in Rome, Georgia from 2003 until 2012 where they were involved in St. Peters Episcopal Church and a variety of civic activities. They returned to Atlanta to be near family. In addition to his immediate family, he leaves a step son, three step daughters, several step grandchildren and step great grandchildren. Mr. Peebles was a long time communicant of the Cathedral of St. Philip. A service will be held there on Monday, March 20th, at 3:00 p.m. with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Cathedral of St. Philip.

Margaret Moore Kennedy GRISWOLD Margaret Moore Griswold was born on Capitol Hill, Seattle, December 18, 1918 to John & Jessie Kennedy. She graduated from Garfield High School in 1937 and worked at Frederick and Nelson until August 2, 1941 when she and Norris were married in her parent's home. Margaret and Norris moved many places, Fairbanks, Anaheim & Seattle, preferring the Northwest. They lived in 16 different houses. They both appreciated the various areas they lived in and felt enlarged by each. Margaret was always (since age 16) been an enthusiastic golfer and hiker. She loved classical and jazz music, good books and pictorial arts. She did wood carving and watercolor. She attended Des Moines Gospel Chapel and through their ministry she became a Christian in 1952. Margaret and Norris had four children. Bill (Sharon) now living in San Diego, Gary (Lois) lives in Boston, Joan (John) Hatchel in West Seattle and Patricia (Clifford) Russell, Lake Oswego Oregon. There are 9 grandchildren and 6 great grand children so far. Her elder sisters Becky and Agnes preceded her in death. Memorial Services are Saturday, August 16, 2003 at 2:00 p.m. at the Des Moines Gospel Chapel. Memorials are suggested to His Fathers Ranch, P.O. Box 13521, Tonasket, WA. 98855 or Highline Hospice.

A memorial guestbook may be signed at www.raderfh.com

Elsie O. Mumaw, 82 of Grafton ( Lucretia Community) passed away on Saturday, May 8, 2004 at Fairmont General Hospital after a brief illness.  She was born on September 21, 1921 in Grafton a daughter of the late Luther and Flora Cox Funk.  She was employed at the West Virginia Industrial School for Boys as a secretary for several years.  She was presently employed in the Taylor County Clerk’s office as a deputy clerk a position she had held for 30 years.  She was a member of the Grafton Business Women and a member of the First Grace Brethren Church in Grafton. In addition to her parents she was preceded in death by her husband; Lloyd Mumaw and one sister; Hazel McDaniel. She is survived by two sisters; Alta Crist of Charlotte, NC, Dorothy Hoffman of Albany, CA, two brothers; Joe Funk of Lakeland, FL and Herb Funk of Arlington, VA. Funeral services will be held 2:00 p.m. Thursday, May 13, 2004 at the Bartlett Funeral Home with the Rev. Joshua Brown officiating.  Interment will follow in Woodsdale Memorial Park, Grafton. Friends may call at the funeral home from 2-9 p.m. on Wednesday. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the First Grace Brethren Church of Grafton.  Condolences may be extended to the family at www.bartlettfunerals.com.

John "Ray" Sobotka, 77, of Springdale, died Wednesday, April 24, 2019. He was born Nov. 17, 1941, in New Kensington, to the late John J. and Cecelia (Kaniecki) Sobotka. He was a 1959 graduate of Springdale High School. Ray was the owner of the former Sobotka's Market, Natrona, for many years. He then went to work for Community Market, working in the meat department as a meat cutter. He was a member of the West Deer VFD No. 1 and was a constable of elections in West Deer. He enjoyed watching his cowboy movies and series, especially John Wayne movies. Survivors include his children, Anita M. Sobotka, at home, Michael J. Sobotka, of Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., and Jeannie R. (Ed) Skripets, of Springdale; his companion of 11 years, Bernadette Mundy, of West Deer; sister, Anita (Rodger) Cleis, of Harwick; sisters-in-law, Helen (Pastierik) Sobotka, of Springdale, and Marcy Funkouser, of Springdale; and many nieces and nephews and his furry friend, Leo. Besides his parents, he was preceded in death by his wife, Carol J. (Pearson) Sobotka, Dec. 31, 2004, his brother, David Sobotka, and his brother-in-law, Gary Funkhouser. Friends will be received from 6 to 8 p.m. Saturday April 27, 2019, and from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. Sunday, April 28, 2019, in the SIWICKI-YANICKO FUNERAL HOME, 23 McKrell Road, Russellton, West Deer Township, where parting prayers will be conducted at 9:30 a.m. Monday, April 29, 2019, with a Catholic funeral Mass following in Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church, Russellton, West Deer, with the Rev. James P. Holland, officiating. He will be laid to rest next to his wife in Mt. Airy Cemetery, Harrison Township. View obituary and leave condolences at www.siwicki-yanickofh.com.

ROBERT ALFRED BARNES - 81, of Greenwich, husband of the late Helen Scully Barnes, passed away peacefully at home Friday evening, December 9th.Mr. Barnes was born in Greenwich January 4, 1924, son of the late W. Everett and Adelheide Scherer Barnes and has been a lifelong resident. He was a 1941 graduate of Greenwich High School and attended the University of Connecticut. During World War II Bob joined the Navy and following boot camp in Newport, RI, he volunteered for the submarine service and attended battery-gyro school. He was assigned to new construction at Electric Boat in Groton and served on the commissioning crew of the U.S.S. Angler (SS240) on which he made three war patrols in the south pacific out of the home port of Fremantle, Australia. Bob was then transferred to the U.S.S. Gurnard (SS254) and made three more war patrols until the war in the pacific ended.Following the war he completed studies to become a Funeral Director and Embalmer and was licensed in the State of Connecticut where he was associated with the Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home for fifty years. He is past president and board member of the Greenwich Exchange Club, a member of Submarine Vets of World War II, the Navy League and the Naval Institute. Bob was appointed as Greenwich Harbor Master by Gov. Lowell Weicker and served from 1991 through 1994. He is an original member of Christ Church Boys Choir under the direction of Claude Means, he also served as co-chair for Lowell P. Weicker Campaign for Connecticut Governor; he is a charter member and former director of the Greenwich Horseneck Club.Bob was a member of the Old Greenwich Yacht Club, owned a 22' sailboat moored in Tod's Point Point Cove and sailed Long Island Sound for forty years making numerous trips up and down the eastern seaboard as far as Tortola B.V.I.Survivors include one son, David Everett Barnes of Greenwich, Ct., three daughters, Cheryl B. McMahon of Chestnut Ridge, NY, Elise B. Kennedy of Sanibel Island, FL, and Juliette B. Rota of Greenwich, Ct.; one sister, Jean B. Burr of Dennis, MA, a dear friend, Karen, three grandchildren, Erin M. Johnson, Lynda M. DiMena, Samantha Kennedy and two great grandchildren, Nicholas Johnson, and Kayla DiMena. he was also predeceased by one son, R. Macy Barnes.Friends are invited to attend a funeral service Wednesday 10:30 am at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Ave., Greenwich. Private interment will take place in Union Cemetery. The family will receive friends Tuesday from 4 to 8 pm in the Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home, 267 Greenwich Ave. Greenwich, CT. Contributions in memory of Bob may be made to a charity of choice.

Rosella M. Toppenberg passed away Feb. 4, 2008, in Sacramento at the age of 90.   Born in Buffalo County, Neb. on Nov. 24, 1917, to the late Frank A. Richter and Ottilla Pauline "Dotty" Litty. While attending business school in Iowa City, her eyes met those of Otto Toppenberg in Reich's Cafe. Their marrage of 1939 was interrupted by Otto's service with the U.S. Navy and his work on the Alcan Highway. During that period Rosella lived in Iowa City, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Seattle. The couple moved to California in 1949, and Rosella spent 38 years with the U.S. Postal Service where she became Hesperia's Assistant Postmaster.  She retired in 1984.  She leaves behind her children; Christine of Las Vegas; Janet (Denny Lewis) of Galt; Lily of Sacramento; and Val (Susan) of West Sacramento; and her dear grandchildren, Alec and Kelly. She worked tirelessly to help provide for her children and help them attend college, but always had time for kids activities and clubs.  Preceded in death by her husband, Otto; sisters Helen Hand (Russ); Katherine Thomas (George); Pauline Priebe (Earl); and Loretta True (Harry); and brothers Joseph (Pat); and Kenneth.  Also survived by sisters Edith Grantham (Wilfred); Francis Behn (Harry) and Waunita Kouba (Stanley); and brother Harold (Billie).   Memorial services will be held on March 17, 2008, at 10:30 a.m. at Riverside National Cemetary. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, remembrances to the Alzheimer's Assocation, Yolo Hospice or the Asian Community Nursing Home in Sacramento in recognition of their kind assistance to Rosella and her family.

He also leaves behind many aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. He was predeceased by a brother Ervin Voisine. Will loved old western movies and country music. Jerold Harris  September 2, 1941 - January 15, 2021  Parkville, Missouri - Jerold Lewis Harris, 79, of Parkville, MO passed away on Friday, January 15, 2021 at McCrite Plaza at Briarcliff. Jerold was born September 2, 1941 to Ansyl L. and LaVern (Divan) Harris in Gordon, NE.  He graduated from Colorado State University in 1963 and began a career with the Farm Credit System. He retired as President and Chief Executive Officer of US AgBank, FCB, Wichita, KS in January 2007. He served on the board of directors of American AgCredit, Santa Rosa, CA until 2017.  Jerold loved a cold beer, going fishing, road trips and his family. He will be sadly missed by all who knew him and loved him. He was truly our hero!  Jerold is survived by his loving wife, Janet Harris; three children: David Harris (Shannon) of Wichita, KS; Susan Woodard (David) of Cheney, KS; Brett Bird (Allison) of Phoenix, AZ; six grandchildren: Blake Harris; Reanna Lynn (Gordon); Dylan Woodard; Abigail Woodard; Ava Bird; Bennie Bird; Trevor Lathrop and Jared Lathrop; three great-grandchildren: Gordon Lynn IV; Waylon Lynn and Jaxton Lynn. He was preceded in death by both parents, a brother, Eugene and a sister Geraldine "Gerry".  The family would like to thank the staff of McCrite Plaza at Briarcliff and especially Stephanie Leu of Kansas City Hospice and Palliative Care and the Care team.  No formal services will be held at this time. In lieu of flowers Memorial contributions are suggested to Children's Mercy Hospital, Kansas City, MO and may be left in care of Meyers Northland Chapel. Memories of Jerold and condolences to the family may be shared at meyersfuneralchapel.com Arr: Cremation arrangements entrusted with Meyers Northland Chapel in Parkville, MO.

Alice S. Merrill of Fort Walton Beach passed away peacefully in her sleep on April 19, 2008. Mrs. Merrill was born in Repton, Ala., on Aug. 18, 1917, to Albert and Minnie Henderson Stringer. She was a retired retail sales associate having worked many years for Leon's in Fort Walton Square and in Santa Rosa Mall. Mrs. Merrill was an accomplished seamstress and she enjoyed reading, solving puzzles, working in her yard and watching birds.    Mrs. Merrill is pre-deceased by her parents, her husband of 40 years, J.C. Merrill, and her grandson, Timothy Carl Merrill. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Carl T. and Harriet C. Merrill of Mobile; her daughter, Sandra M. Lefstad of Fort Walton Beach, and her daughter and son-in-law Marsha and David Smith of Jacksonville, Ala. Mrs. Merrill leaves two granddaughters, Alice McIntosh of Mobile, and Carole Shea of Alexandria, Va.; one grandson, Steven Taylor Park of Fort Walton Beach; and two great grandsons, Josh Everett and Matt McIntosh of Mobile.    Funeral services for Mrs. Merrill will be held on Monday, April 21, 2008 at 11 a.m. at the Emerald Coast Funeral Home, 113 Racetrack Road N.E., Fort Walton Beach. Dr. Mickey Hawkins, Pastor of Cinco Baptist Church will conduct the service. The family will receive friends for viewing and visitation at 10 a.m. prior to the service. A private burial with family members will follow in Castleberry, Ala.    Floral expressions of sentiment would be welcome; however, in lieu of flowers, donations to Emerald Coast Hospice would be an appreciated tribute.    Mrs. Merrill's family would like to thank Dr. Vergil Brown, Mrs. Betty Dreumont, and many Emerald Coast Hospice caregivers for their gracious, ender care and assistance provided to her.    You may express condolences and sign the guest register at www.emeraldcoastfuneralhome.com

Leon Wilbur Strosnider, 70, of Stephens City, Virginia, died Tuesday, May 27, 2014, in Winchester Medical Center surrounded by family and friends.Leon was born in 1943 in Winchester, Virginia, the son of Nevaline Strosnider of Stephens City and the late Wilbur Joseph Strosnider. He was a graduate of James Wood High School and Reisch Auctioneering School in Mason City, Iowa. He was a self employed Auctioneer for over 43 years, a lifelong member of Refuge United Methodist Church and a member of the Clarke County Ruritan. He was passionate about auctioneering and was the first auctioneer in the local area to attend auctioneering school. Alfons A. "Al" Kluthe, 97, of Fremont died Sunday, Oct. 5, 2003, at Pathfinder House in Fremont. Kluthe was born May 28, 1906, in Dodge. He attended school in Olean and grew up near Dodge. He lived on a farm between Snyder and Scribner where he farmed for 10 years. He moved to West Point and was employed at the Farmers Union Store for 10 years. He moved to Fremont in 1960 and worked at Montgomery Ward & Co. as a receiving clerk and then worked at Dave's Drive-In Liquor for 20 years. He married Irene Ulrich on Jan. 16, 1940, in Monterey. She preceded him in death June 27, 1976. He was a member of St. Patrick's Catholic Church in Fremont and a member of the Knights of Columbus Council 1497 at Fremont. He was a former member of the Fraternal Order of Eagles at Fremont. Survivors include: a daughter, Jeanette (Mrs. Norbert) Starman of Elgin; a brother, Edmund (and wife, Clara) Kluthe of Las Vegas; five sisters, Philemena Steffensmeier of Sioux Falls, S.D., Camilla Ulrich of Omaha, Ann Marie Kluthe and Micky Kluthe, both of Fremont, and Bernadine Kluthe of Dodge; two stepgrandchildren and two stepgreat-grandchildren. He also was preceded in death by four sisters. The funeral will be 10:30 a.m. Wednesday at St. Patrick's Catholic Church in Fremont with the Rev. Owen Korte officiating. A Knights of Columbus rosary will be said at 7 p.m. Tuesday at Moser Memorial Chapel in Fremont. Visitation will be from 1-9 p.m. Tuesday at the funeral home and continues one hour prior to service time at the church. Burial will be in Calvary Cemetery in Fremont. A memorial has been established to St. Patrick's Catholic Church in Fremont.

Barbara Taylor Social worker; 1925-2014 Barbara Taylor of Montclair, N.J., passed away on Oct. 12, 2014. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Church, 67 Church St., Montclair, on Saturday, Nov. 29, from 1 to 5 p.m. Barbara, the first child of Robert F. and Bethel Stevenson, was born Jan. 25, 1925, in Brooklyn, N.Y. The family lived in Englewood, N.J., prior to moving to Montclair. Barbara graduated from Montclair High in 1943 and earned a bachelor's degree from Fisk University in 1947. Barbara held several positions in social work prior to becoming a caseworker for the Essex County Welfare Board in 1959. She earned an MSW from Rutgers in 1977. Barbara retired from the welfare board in 1986 and became a social worker for the East Orange Board of Education until retiring 1995. Barbara married Samuel Taylor on Dec. 6, 1952. They were blessed with two sons, Geoffrey B. Taylor (deceased) and William J. Taylor. She also had two granddaughters, Taylor Alice Marie Jones and Samora Stevenson Jones (deceased). Barbara's husband, Sam Taylor, passed away in 2003. Barbara was a member of Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, The Montclair Drifters, the Crawford Crews American Legion Unit, The Four Seasons Bridge Club, and the National Council of Negro Women (NCNW). Barbara was the granddaughter of Ann and Edward Spencer, whose home and garden is a registered national and state historic site in Virginia, www.annespencermuseum.com. Barbara is survived by her son, William Taylor; sister, Ann S. Johnson; granddaughter, Taylor Jones; grandchildren, Kyle and Tayah Spady; dear friend, Jimmie Jones; several nieces, nephews, many beloved friends; her sorority sisters of Alpha Kappa Alpha, and cherished companions with the Montclair Drifters.

Sept. 6, 1937 - July 15, 2004 Masako Inuzuka Atteberry of Corvallis died Thursday in Corvallis. She was 66. She was born in Tokyo, Japan, to Yoshio and Misao (Fujita) Inuzuka. She grew up in Tokyo and received a scholarship to Western Washington University, where she earned a bachelor's degree in education. She married Pat Atteberry. They eventually moved to Corvallis. She taught art and Japanese to kindergarten through 12th-grade students, as well as giving instruction to private companies. Molly Ann Lindsey Studenroth, a kind-hearted individual with an unwavering dedication to her family and community, passed away on Friday, September 22, 2023. Molly was born on May 27, 1946, in Chicago, Illinois to James and Myrtle Goin Lindsey. Throughout her life, she touched countless lives with her generosity, compassion, and commitment.Molly began her professional journey as a teller, showcasing exceptional skills and becoming a familiar face to many in the Elizabethtown, Kentucky community. For over 15 years, Molly diligently served the public as a teller.  She dedicated 10 years at First Hardin National Bank, where she worked tirelessly to ensure the financial well-being of others.While Molly's career was remarkable, it only scratched the surface of her incredible character and passions. Cats held a special place in Molly's heart; she carried an immense love for felines and made it her duty to rescue as many as possible. Countless animals found solace in her care and were fortunate enough to experience all-encompassing love. Her nurturing spirit never faded and will be deeply missed by the feline friends she left behind.Genealogy also captivated Molly's interest; delving into family connections brought her great joy. She spent countless hours poring over historical records and tracing family branches that had long been forgotten. Through her dedication to genealogy, Molly strengthened familial bonds and built bridges that spanned generations. Her passion for connecting relatives was truly remarkable.Molly was predeceased by her beloved husband Karl R. Studenroth in 1980 along with three sisters and three brothers. She cherished the memories they made together throughout their married life and carried their legacy within her heart.Left to cherish their memories are those whom Molly held dear. Her son, Karl Studenroth, will forever carry his mother's love with him, taking solace in the countless memories they shared; two sisters; and three brothers.  Molly's impact reached far beyond her immediate family, touching the lives of extended family members and close friends who will remember her warm smile and unwavering support.Molly Lindsey Studenroth lived a life filled with love and a dedication to her passions. Her compassion for animals, commitment to the community, and zeal for genealogy were guiding forces that brought joy to all those fortunate enough to know her. As we bid farewell to this remarkable woman, let us be comforted by the fact that her spirit lives on through the lives she touched and the everlasting memories she created. To celebrate her life, a memorial service is being planned for next spring.May Molly's soul find eternal rest as she reunites with loved ones who have gone before her. She will forever hold a special place in our hearts, and her goodness will continue to inspire all who have had the privilege of knowing her. The care of Mrs. Studenroth has been entrusted to Wells Funeral Home of Canton and an online memorial register is available at "Obituaries" at www.wellsfuneralhome.com.

Marilyn Norman, of Montevideo, died Thursday, May 19, 2022 at Centracare - St. Cloud Hospital at the age of 87.Funeral services will be held on Thursday, May 26, 2022 at 1:00 PM at Our Saviors Lutheran Church in Montevideo with Rev. Donald S. McKee officiating.Visitation with the family will be held on Wednesday, May 25, 2022 from 5:00 - 7:00 PM at Anderson – TeBeest Funeral Home in Montevideo with a prayer service beginning at 6:30 PM. Visitation will continue one hour prior to the service at church on Thursday.Arrangements are with Anderson – TeBeest Funeral Home of Montevideo.Marilyn Alva Norman (Amundson) was born April 25, 1935 in Benson, MN to Harris and Mable (Alsaker) Amundson. She was baptized and confirmed into the Christian Faith. She was united in marriage to Milo Norman Jr. at Our Saviors Lutheran Church in Montevideo in 1951. They moved to Edina where Marilyn spent time working as a butcher at Jerry’s Lucky Dollar. Milo and Marilyn moved to Madison in 1967 and settled in Montevideo in 1970, where she worked at Trailways Café for 34 years, retiring in 2004.Marilyn enjoyed crocheting and knitting, and with this talent she made many creations for her family and friends. She was also an excellent baker and cook. Marilyn had a love for fishing, which she shared that love with her family. She even taught a class in Montevideo on fishing and how to use certain equipment. Marilyn was an active member of Our Saviors Lutheran Church, at Heritage Hill, and the Ford Fordson National Collectors Club.She is survived by her children, Bruce Norman of Montevideo, Jenell (Kurt) Dahl of Montevideo, Brian (Patty) Norman of Granite Falls, Kevin (Sarah) Norman of Montevideo, and Tom (Deanne) Norman of Montevideo; grandchildren, Matthew and Adam Norman, Tanya (Jeff) Vanden Einde, Lori (Mike) Huntley, Tim Dahl, Jason Norman (Michelle Magnuson), Candice (Jamey) Freese, Morgan and Isabelle Norman, Kayla (Caleb) Cornelius, and Brandon (Jackie) Norman; several great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren; special friend and partner of 22 years, Doug Norman; brothers, Roger (Charolett) Amundson, Dorvin (Karen) Amundson, Dennis Amundson, and Kenny (MaryJane) Amundson; sister, Irene (Kelly) Lindblad; and several nieces, nephews, extended family and friends.She was preceded in death by her parents, and brother, Jerry.

William Charles “Chuck” Drake, age 58, of Yukon, OK, passed away on Thursday, July 6, 2023 in Oklahoma City from complications related to pneumonia.He is preceded in death by his grandmother, Lola King, grandfather, Virgil King, and uncle, Dean King. He leaves behind his wife, Cheryl, and three children, Ashley, Megan, and Justin. He also leaves behind his mother, Lawana King Bray, father, Danny George (Sharry), and brother, Joe (Valerie). Chuck was a family man and made an effort to spend time with all of his extended family: his parents-in-law, Ed and Sharon Turk of Chandler, sisters-in-law Debbie (Glen) and Vicky (Paul), step siblings David (Kim) and Marjorie (Adam), nieces Jessica (Blain), Devin, Rebecca, Alexis, and Elizabeth (Larry), and nephews Micah (Ashley), Andrew (Charlotte), and Caden.Chuck was a loyal husband, loving father, devoted son, and avid hunter and fisherman. He was born on July 24, 1964 in Cushing, OK. He graduated from Grace Christian Academy in Oklahoma City. Chuck met his beloved wife, Cheryl Turk Drake, formerly of Chandler, while working as an armored guard for a bank in downtown Oklahoma City, where Cheryl worked in the vaults. He would always bring her candy before finally asking to see her outside of work. They married on August 7, 1993. As they welcomed their three children, Chuck was committed to teaching his children, nieces and nephews, and any who wanted to learn a love of fishing and the outdoors. For many years, he was involved in an annual fishing derby for kids, where he would convince novice anglers that they should kiss the worm for good luck, and he also competed semiprofessionally in bass fishing tournaments with his fishing partner, Roy Fryer. Each year, he took a trip to visit his friend Cecil’s cabin in McAlester, OK with at least one of his children, where they hunted and made lifelong friends and memories. Chuck worked at Tinker Air Force Base as a third generation civilian mechanic for 25+ years, first as an aircraft electrician on B-52s, and later as an aircraft analyst. Whenever groups visited for tours, Chuck was the person who showed them around with great pride and humorous storytelling. But wherever he was, the topics he could talk about the most about were his pride regarding his wife and children, and, usually, whatever bass fishing tournament in which he’d recently participated.Chuck is remembered as a generous friend who gave all that he could; he could be counted on to lend a helping hand for household projects and keep you entertained with a long, humorous story after he finished it. In his last act of generosity, Chuck was an organ donor, and even in death is giving someone else a chance at life. In all facets of his life, Chuck leaves behind a legacy of humor, hard work, generosity, and loyalty.Visitation will be held on Monday, July 10 from 6:00 to 8:00 p.m. at Buchanan Funeral Service, and Tuesday, July 11 from 11:00 a.m. to 12:45 p.m. at New Heights Baptist Church. Services will be held immediately following the Tuesday visitation at the church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Casts for Kids, a charity that teaches children with special needs to fish.

Francis P. Aste, 68, of East Andover passed away Tuesday, January 13, 2015.Francis was born in Woburn, Mass. on October 8, 1946 to Joseph and Anna (Criss) Aste. He earned an Associate's degree in electronics from NHTI in Concord and applied his knowledge as a supervisor with BEA Systems in Nashua. Francis was an Army Veteran who was stationed in Vietnam from 1968 to 1970 with Battery C of the National Guard Unit out of Franklin, N.H.; one of the top artillery units. He received an honorable discharge and was awarded the National Defense Service Medal, the Vietnam Campaign Ribbon w/ 60 Device, the Vietnam Service Medal and one overseas bar. Francis was a HAM radio operator under the call sign WA1VTS. He was deeply devoted to his family.Francis is survived by his wife, Susan (Perreault) Aste; his son, Paul L. Aste; his daughter-in-law, Leann; his grandchildren, Andrea and Sarah; his mother, Anna Bailey; and many dear friends. He was predeceased by his father, Joseph Aste. A graveside service with military honors will take place Thursday, January 22nd at 1 p.m. at the New Hampshire State Veterans Cemetery, 110 Daniel Webster Highway, Boscawen, N.H.The Cremation Society of New Hampshire, Boscawen office, is assisting the family with arrangements. For more information please go to csnh.com.

There are no words that one could write to fully describe this amazing young man. As a kid, Stephen loved the great outdoors, riding his bike, and hanging out (or getting into trouble) with his brothers and friends. At age 16, Stephen was paralyzed from the chest down, as a result of an accident. He never let it define who he was or wanted to be in life. Stephen continued his love of fishing and hunting at the family farm. Even with his challenges, he was still able to shoot the largest deer in the field. Stephen always found a way to make people laugh with his quick jokes and his infectious smile which would always brighten the room. Family was very important to him, as he enjoyed the many family gatherings and quality time with everyone, accompanied by his English bulldog and faithful companion, Gus. He also really enjoyed spoiling his niece and nephew. Stephen just had a way about him that will leave an enduring legacy of courage, strength, and fortitude in the face of such unimaginable adversity. Stephen was preceded in death by his Grandmother, Betty Joann Gibson, Grandfather, Robert JosephRountree, and Aunt, Robyn Rountree Bunce. Stephen is survived by his Father, Robert LeeRountree, Mother, Teresa Tule, Brothers, Joseph Rountree and Justin Rountree, Sisters, CheyenneRountree and Alexis Tule, Grandparents, Monyeen and George Cooper, Aunts, Kristin Rountree Voigt and Tracy Price, Uncles, Terry Price and David Bunce, Niece, Anabella Rountree, Nephew, Simon Rountree, Special Cousins: Monica Bunce, Maggi, Ryan, Vincent and Leo Carmichael, Connor and Lucas Greer, Ethan Voigt, Kristin Young, Kody Cross, Geoffrey Price, Lauren LeVesque, and Sadie White, and childhood friend, Christopher Martinez. Stephen will be forever loved and missed by many.Visitation will be held at Cashner Funeral Home in Conroe, Texas on Wednesday, July 7, 2021, from 5:00pm to 7:00pm. Funeral service for Stephen Allen Rountree will be held at the Cashner Colonial Chapel on Thursday, July 8. 2021 at 2:00pm. There will be a private family interment.
Burial arrangements under the direction of National Memorial Park.

When I come to the end of the road and the sun has set for me I want no rites in a gloom-filled room. Why cry for a soul that's set free. Miss me a little, but not too long and not with your head bowed low. Remember the love that we once shared. Miss me, but let me go. For this is a journey that we all must take and each must go alone. It's all a part of the Master's plan, a step on the road to home. When you are lonely and sick of heart, go to the friends we knew and laugh at the things that we used to do. Miss me, but let me go.

Betty J. Nicholas, 98, longtime resident of Lake Nebagamon, WI went to her heavenly home on May 6, 2021.She was born February 15, 1923 in Middle River, WI to Gustaf and Ida (Smestad) Gronquist, the fourth of five daughters. Betty spent her early years in Rockmont before moving to Superior, where she graduated from Central High School. She worked at the Franklin Creamery to help pay off the family dairy bill. Later she worked at the co-op wholesale building packing coffee and operating their switchboard. She married Lindy Nicholas at Concordia Lutheran Church in Superior on July 12, 1947. They raised three boys together: Charles Linfred, James Scott, and Steven Tate.Betty and Lindy exemplified the commitment and determination so prevalent in that ‘greatest’ generation. Betty worked alongside Lindy building their house including mixing mortar and tending block. She also painted with watercolors and enjoyed photography, sign painting, sewing, baking, and cooking. She was a leader with 4-H. Betty helped Lindy and his cousin start a golf course in the 60’s and ran it while the men were working. She was an avid golfer for many decades. Her example encouraged her boys and many others to face life with patience, determination, and compassion.Betty became a widow in 1997 after caring for Lindy during his many years of kidney failure. She lovingly helped raise two of her granddaughters, Lesley and Carah Nicholas and opened her home to many, showing selfless hospitality.Betty was preceded in death by her parents, her four sisters Doris Farmer, Alice Kinser, Lois Anderson, and Edna Tatge.She is survived by her three sons, Charles (Shirley), James (Shannon), and Steven (Tami); 5 grandchildren: Cameron, Trevor (Renee), Carah, Lesley, Emma (Ja’lon); great grandchildren Ethan and Everett (Trevor and Renee), and numerous nieces and nephews including Phyllis and Tom Flaherty who cared for her when she could no longer live alone. William Hendry Father, mechanical engineer and veteran, 89 William Hendry, 89, of Cranford, N.J., passed away on March 1, 2016. Funeral services will be held on Saturday, March 5, 2016, at 9:30 a.m. in The Gray Memorial Funeral Home, 12 Springfield Ave., Cranford. Interment will follow at Somerset Hills Memorial Park, Basking Ridge, N.J. Visitation and Life Celebration will be on Friday, March 4, 2016, from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at the funeral home. Born in Harrison, N.J., Mr. Hendry lived in Cranford for 55 years. He served in the U.S. Coast Guard during World War II, and then in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. He spent the majority of his career as a mechanical engineer with Western Electric Co. and AT&T. He also spent many years teaching college as an adjunct faculty member at NJIT and Union County College. Over the years, he was a member of the Cranford VFW Post 335, the Masonic Lodge, the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, Foundation for Diabetes Research, and was a member and elder of Osceola Presbyterian Church. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Gladys, and is survived by his sons, William and his wife, Jennifer, Bruce, and Brian. He is also survived by his granddaughters, Melissa and Kristen. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Foundation for Diabetes Research, 513 West Mount Pleasant Ave., Suite 220, Livingston, N.J. 07039, diabetesnj.org.

ObituaryIt is with profound sadness that the McNulty family shares the news of the passing of Emily, their family’s matriarch, mother, “Glam-ma”, great “Glam-ma”, aunt, godmother and treasured friend to so many, in the early morning hours of Monday, June 26th. She was 98 years old (1925-2023). Emily truly lived a life well lived.Born by a mid-wife at home (often common in 1925), she was the daughter of George and Anna Gago who had immigrated from Czechoslovakia. Not many can say this, but Emily lived her entire 98 years within a 50 block radius in the greater Milwaukee area. Always impeccably dressed and coifed with a keen sense of style in fashion and home decorating, her French twist hairstyle was her signature.She was a graduate of the class of 1939 from St. Michael’s Grade School. St. Michael’s perhaps has one of the most active and well run alumni programs in the country (remember this is a grade school!). Emily was passionately active in running key year reunions for her class, even hosting the 70th in her home and garden.Emily had many fond memories and again established lifelong friendships when she attended Holy Angels Academy, graduating with the class of 1943. Once again, she used her creative talents to spearhead the reunions to ensure they were well orchestrated with eye catching invitations, angel name tags, programs and centerpieces.Emily was honored to be awarded 1 of the 7 Boston Store Retail College Scholarships, assisting her to attend Marquette University. She was so proud to represent Marquette University on the Boston Store College Travel Bureau reception committee, modeling for their fashion shows and working as an assistant buyer in Better Sportswear. She earned her BA in Business Administration in 1948. At Marquette, she met the love of her life and future husband of 53 years, Truman Quentin McNulty, who she fondly referred to as “Tru-heart”. His exceptional ballroom dancing skills and many MU mixers sealed the deal. She had a storybook wedding in 1950, with her wedding dress from Hixon’s, reception in the Imperial Grand Ballroom of the Pfister Hotel, a full orchestra and 300 in attendance.Family was everything to Emily. She provided her children/grandchildren with guidance, discipline, strength, family values, work ethic and was supportive of their dreams. 110% of her focus was on her husband and raising her children, Mark, Mary Kay, Brian, and Erin. She was often teased for having the perfectly planned Catholic family, having them two years a part.! Her career became roles, such as scout den mother of Pack 56, Den 7, supreme hostess of countless elaborately decorated themed birthday parties for the children, Marquette High School Mother’s Guild, DSHA Parent’s Club, and more. On her husband’s side, a member of Milwaukee Lawyer’s Wives (hosting May 1 Law Day for new USA citizens), State Bar of Wisconsin and ABA Lawyer’s Wives, board member of Marquette University Association of Women, and hosted the MU “Dinner for 12 Strangers” that brought new students and faculty together. She also devoted time to two Wauwatosa Women’s Clubs, was a lifetime member of the Christ Child Society and Slovak Catholic Sokols Wreath 93. Always very proud of her 100% Slovak heritage. She was a consummate host to home dinner parties, Washington Highland’s newcomer parties, coffees for various political candidates, and too many more to mention.What was truly remarkable about Emily was her wide range of friends from all backgrounds and ages, sometimes 25 years her junior to 20 years her senior, who came to her for advice, decorating tips, recipes, serving dishes, party planning decorations, etc. She was even nominated by a young, just married lawyer for the Milwaukee Journal Best Cook on the Block publication.Emily always said she lived a charmed life. A travel agent friend of her once told her “You are not considered well traveled until you book passage on the QE-2, fly the Concorde and ride the Orient Express.” Emily accomplished all 3. She treasured her two trips to her mother’s home village in Slovakia, once with her mother and 25 years later with her daughter. One of her cherished memories was attending the Presidential Inauguration and Ball in Washington DC.Emily’s last years were graced by the immeasurably compassionate care and loving, loyal and constant support of Betty V. Heartfelt thanks to the other caregivers who also supported Emily on her final journey. They all were instrumental in allowing her to stay in the Highland’s home she treasured since 1971.Just a glimpse into the life of a 98 year old woman who gave so much to so many for them to succeed and enjoy life.Emily is reunited in heaven with her husband Truman (2004), daughter Erin (2010), son Mark (2019), brother Rudy Gago (1983) and her faithful canine companion Riley (2021). She leaves to celebrate her life her devoted daughter Mary Kay of San Francisco, loving son Brian (Luanne) of Green Bay, cherished grandchildren Natalie Bowling (Scott), Kelly, Brigette and Sam and great-grandson Ace Bowling, along with many other relatives and friends. Visitation for Emily will be on Friday, July 7th from 4 PM – 7 PM at Wisconsin Memorial Park, Chapel of the Chimes, 13235 W. Capitol Dr. Brookfield. Mass will be on Saturday, July 8th at 12 Noon, with eulogies at 11:50 AM, at St. Sebastian Catholic Church, 5400 W. Washington Blvd., Milwaukee. Private interment.Contributions to the Truman & Emily McNulty Scholarship and Award Fund at Marquette University Law School (Checks may be made payable to Marquette University Law School, with McNulty Fund written in the memo line. Please mail checks to Marquette University, PO Box 7013, Carol Stream, IL 60197-7013.) or the Wisconsin Humane Society (4500 West Wisconsin Avenue, Milwaukee, WI 53208) requested.Mom, you are now reunited with dad and enjoying a ballroom dance that will last an eternity. As was your telephone ritual with Brigette, we say to you “we love you, we love you more, we love you the mostest, we love you to the moon and now love you to the heavens”.To send flowersto the family or plant a treein memory of Emily Ann (Gago) McNulty, please visit our floral store.

On Sunday, February 5th, Stanley M “STAN” Stark of 1628 Courthouse Rd left this earth to once again join his loving wife Wanda in eternal embrace.Stanley was born on August 16th, 1939, in Brattleboro, Vermont to Malcolm and Stella Stark. Born a few years before the attack on Pearl Harbor, Stanley and his family moved several times during his childhood. World War II was on, and Malcolm Stark moved his family from Vermont to Massachusetts, Topsham Maine, and Washington tate in search of work. Shortly after the war, Stanley and his family returned to Maine.Stanley spent his remaining childhood in small, rural New England where he developed an unmatched work ethic logging in the woods of Maine while employed at his fathers’ sawmill.Stanley graduated from Appleton High School and enlisted in the United States Navy in 1957. This would be the beginning of a remarkable military career that saw Stanley serving his country in Europe, Africa, the Indian Ocean, and Vietnam. During his impeccable military career Stanley rose to the rank of Master Chief Petty Officer, the highest rank afforded to enlisted personnel. It was during his first tour of duty in Naples, Italy, that Stan would meet and fall in love with his beloved wife Wanda. For 58 years Stan and Wanda would build an unshakeable marriage that would lead them on adventures across the world and see them raise three children. Stan and Wanda exemplified complete and total love, joy, and commitment. This wonderful bond would live on well beyond Wandas’ passing in 2018.In recent years, Stan discovered his passion for salt and freshwater kayaking. Stan competed in many races throughout the Southeast and loved paddling with his new group of friends.The older, wiser Stan was dubbed the “Zenmaster” by his new-found brotherhood. In July of 2020, Stan embarked on his dream of paddling the entire length of the Mississippi River. What appeared to be an “impossible dream” that began in a tiny town in Minnesota ended some 2500 miles later in the Gulf of Mexico as Stanley became the oldest man in history to accomplish this feat at 81 years of age. For those who knew Stan, none were surprised. He loved the bond he formed with these men and women with whom he shared the winding rivers.Stanley leaves behind two brothers, James Stark and Malcolm Stark Jr. Stan also leaves a sister, Molly Leigher and was pre-deceased by sister Nancy Turner.Of all the many achievements and accomplishments that Stanley Stark was credited with, there are none greater than having been a devoted husband to his wife, adoring grandfather to his three grandchildren, Marty, Sam and Haley, and an amazing father to his three children. Stanley leaves behind two daughters, Linda Baker and her husband Kelly Baker and Ada Stewart and her husband James Stewart, both from Gulfport and a son, Larry Stark, and his wife Diana Stark from Maine.Dad, we love you and can’t imagine a better father and role model. Simply put, Stan Stark made everyone he came in contact with a better person for knowing him.Your soul is free to join your darling Wanda and free to paddle greater waters.Friends are invited to join the family for visitation and services on Saturday, February 11, 2023, at Riemann Family Funeral Home, 11280 Three Rivers Road, Gulfport. Visitation will be held from 10:00 to 11:00 a.m., with the Funeral Service at 11:00 a.m. Mr. Stark will be laid to rest at Floral Hills Memorial Gardens in Gulfport.

Clifford John Palacio was born and partially raised in Seine Bight, a quintessential Garifuna village in Belize.  Born on May 6, 1930, Clifford John Palacio was the eldest son of Santiaga and Fulgencio Palacio. He attended school under one of Belize's most outstanding Garifuna teachers, Simeon M. Sampson, Sr. (a.k.a. Master Bam). After Clifford’s father returned from Scotland during World War II in 1942, at the age of fifteen, his family moved from Seine Bight to Dangriga Town where he continued his elementary education at Sacred Heart School managed by the Sisters of the Holy Family. In 1946, when Primary School Certificate examination was first introduced in Belize by the Colonial Education Department, young Clifford passed the test qualifying him to become a pupil (student) teacher. On January 13, 1947, Clifford's teaching career officially began. At the age of nineteen, together with then Garifuna student-teachers Eugene Hernandez, Augustine Flores, and George Guerrero, he attended St. John's College (high school) under a Jesuit Mission teacher-training scholarship program initiated by late Fr. John M. Knopp S.J., Superior. (Those were part of the Garifuna cream-of-the-crop historically selected and trained for missionary work in rural Belize.) While in St. John's College (high school.), together with Theodore Palacio, Austin Flores, Eugene Hernandez and Govel Morgan, Clifford Palacio assisted in the compilation of a Garifuna dictionary headed by seminarian John Stochl, S.J. It was the first of its kind ever published in Belize in 1951. The same group of Garifuna students also produced a Catholic prayer book titled "Lebeneri Cielu" --The Gate of Heaven. Clifford’s remarkable class was the first group to graduate from Landívar Campus the new location of St. John’s College. Some members of that student body became prominent public figures of the country. Hon. Curl Thompson became Deputy Prime Minister under the administration of former Prime Minister Manuel Esquivel. Eustace Usher became chief radio announcer of Government Radio Belize. For many years, Charles Woods headed the Labor Department of Belize. Johnny Price became a medical doctor. From Yo Creek, Guadalupe Pech became a politician and held the post of Minister of Education under the administration of Hon. George Cadle Price. Santiago Perdomo also entered politics and became a Minister of government.  Paul Lewis created history by becoming the first principal of Lynam College in Dangriga Town, while Eugene Hernandez held the post of first principal of Muffles College in Orange Town in 1953. This was the first time in the history of Belize that high school education became available to students outside of Belize City.  For fifteen years, Augustine Flores was principal of Ecumenical College in Dangriga Town. Oswald Reyes was ordained a Roman Catholic priest. Over the years, Mr. Palacio accumulated a wealth of experiences as a teacher, as a Garifuna activist and as an effective leader. After graduating from S.J.C. in 1953, Clifford, having passed the First Class Teachers' Exam while still in high school taught in San Jose Palmar, a one-teacher school, one year after pioneer Eugene Hernandez started Muffles College, Orange Walk Town. He later attended St. John's Teacher Training College for two years.In 1955 he married his high-school sweetheart Rita Servio, then a student-teacher. This union produced nine wonderful children, six boys and three girls. Rita, a trained teacher and a Child Development Specialist with the State of California, stood firmly by her husband quietly raising and harmoniously educating their nine successful children. Their careers as a team, teaching in rural Belize, started in San Pedro, Ambergris Caye immediately after their honeymoon. Both Rita and Clifford are multilingual, fluent in Garifuna, Spanish, English, Creole and Clifford some Maya. In 1970 Mr. Palacio migrated to the United States with the aim of providing for his family the opportunity to acquire a college education. One of the girls earned a Ph. D in Instructional technology from USC and another girl earned an M.B.A. from the Catholic University of America; one of the boys played professional basketball with the N.B.A. and Overseas for ten years; one boy is a computer technician. One of the boys is a respiratory therapist. One of the girls is a cosmetologist and healthcare caregiver. One of the boys was a supervisor with AT&T, now an entrepreneur and another boy, with varied skills is a Garifuna artist, a painter and a master drummer. He is also a composer having released some songs. One of the boys was a tool designer in the airplane manufacturing industry, now retired. In 1973, Mr. Palacio joined the Garifuna Settlement Day Committee of Los Angeles. During the time he was secretary and president for sixteen years, he initiated and promoted several trends (Garifuna traditions) in Los Angeles, such as, nine-day-novena culminating in a beluria, Garifuna Mass prayers and hymns, outdoor Garifuna drumming and dancing, annual Settlement Day celebrations, annual dinner dance, yearly excursions from Dangriga, radio program, annual presentation of young Miss Garifuna to the Los Angeles City Council Meeting, Miss Garifuna pageant and traditional Christmas grand ball. This is one of the traditions that our ancestors brought with them from Yurumein in the eighteenth century.           In connection with the promotion and preservation of the Garifuna culture and history, Clifford established contacts with several universities, such as, Columbia University, Stanford University, UCLA, USC, Irvine University, Maryland University and Texas A&M - Commerce University.           After working for thirteen years as an ESL (English as a Second Language) Instructor with Center for Employment Training, Mr. Palacio retired in July of 1997. But his love for teaching did not allow him to stay away all together from classroom teaching and sharing his experiences and knowledge. As a retiree, he got engaged in the teaching of Garifuna history and language pro bono. November 1st, 1999 marked the anniversary of the beginning of an era in the Garifuna history -- the formal study of the Garifuna unique history and language in Los Angeles, California. Clifford's wish was, someday, to have Garifuna history and language taught in all predominant Garifuna communities in Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. Viewing :Friday, August 5, 2022 9:30 a.m. to 10:30 a.m.Holy Cross Mortuary :Room D5835 West Slauson AvenueCulver City, CA 90230Celebrants:Bishop David G. Mr. Robert Lee (R.L.) Fuquea, age 96 of  the Red Bud Community, died  Monday, March 18, 2013 at his residence following an extended illness. He was born in the Pleasant Hill Community in Gordon County on April 28, 1916, son of the late Robert Milton Fuquea and Sally Powell Fuquea, and was preceded in death by a sister, Avanell Fuquea, a brother Ralph Fuquea, and a niece, Phyllis Roberson. Mr. Fuquea was a well known educator, having taught Physics, Biology and Science at Red Bud School for 27 years. He taught the Farm Training Program at Calhoun Veterans School in Calhoun just after graduating from college. He attended Abraham Baldwin Agricultural Collage in Tifton, GA for two years, and was a graduate of the University of Georgia. He was a veteran of the United States Army. Mr. Fuquea was a member of Bethesda Baptist Church, and served as an ordained deacon from 1954 until 2006. He was the chairman of Deacons for 20 years and served as Sunday School Superintendant from 1950 until 1967. He was instrumental in Bethesda Baptist Church progressing from a church with bi-monthly worship services, to having weekly worship services. He organized the Royal Ambassadors Boy's Mission Program and began the van ministry, which is a vital ministry of the church at present.Mr. Fuquea enjoyed the outdoors and tending his gardens. He had established 25 different varieties of apple trees at his farm. Survivors include his loving wife, Geneva Coats Fuquea, to whom he was married for 61 years; a nephew, Terry Fuquea of Marietta, GA; three great-nephews; a great niece; and a great-great nephew.Funeral services for Mr. Robert Lee (R.L.) Fuquea will be conducted Tuesday, March 19th at 1:00 PM from Bethesda Baptist Church, with Pastor Wesley Hunt officiating. Interment will follow in Fain Cemetery. The deacons of Bethesda Baptist Church will serve as active pallbearers. Honorary pallbearers are members of the Bethesda Men's Sunday School Class, and the Bethesda Baptist Adult and Sunday School Class.The family will receive friends Monday between the hours of 5:00 PM and 7:00 PM at Max Brannon and Sons Funeral Home.Online condolences may be expressed and the guest book signed at www.maxbrannonandsons.com. Max Brannon and Sons Funeral Home is in charge of the funeral services for Mr. Robert Lee (R.L.) Fuquea of the Red Bud Community.

Harlan Thomas PierceJanuary/16/1956 - December/9/2022“The song has ended, but the melody lingers on ”Harlan “Thomas” Pierce of Toledo, Ohio was called home unexpectedly on Friday, December 9th, 2022 at the age of 66. The world has lost a great father, grandfather, friend, and loved one.Thomas was born on January 16, 1956 to Harlan and Carol (Martin) Pierce. In his younger years, Tom enjoyed racing dirt bikes and his love of motorcycles was evident throughout the years. He was a former Journeyman Tool and Die Maker, but perhaps that was never his true passion. He was adventurous and enjoyed camping and taking road trips, visiting many state parks across the country in his motorhome. He lived for beautiful scenery. Tom was also a passionate pet lover and considered his pets to be members of his family, speaking to them as people instead of animals. Above all else, Tom was an accomplished musician. He played both the lead and bass guitar and played them well. His heart and soul belonged to music. From his years spent with the Whoodoo Men, playing alongside Josh Boyd and the VIP Band, to his most recent adventure with the Fabulous Disaster, he put everything he had into his music.Tom was most proud of his family. He was very much involved in his grandchildren’s lives, supporting their passions whether it was football, BMX, dirt bikes, go-karts, or most recently the enlistment of his oldest grandson into the Army National Guard. Tom loved his only daughter and never failed to tell her and everyone else how proud of her he was.He was preceded in death by his parents Harlen and Carol, and sister, Susan. He is survived by his only daughter Sarah Pierce (Eric), grandsons Cameron Beasley and Caden Stewart, nieces and nephews Kristin, Amanda and Phillip, his long-time love Joni WhiteCoats, and many dear friends who will miss him deeply.The family will be receiving friends in the Urbanski Funeral Home a Life Celebration Home 5055 Secor Rd Toledo, Ohio on Sunday, December 18, 2022, from 2:00 p.m. until 8:00 p.m. where funeral services will begin at 7:00 p.m.Memorial ServicesThe family will be receiving friends in the Urbanski Funeral Home a Life Celebration Home 5055 Secor Rd Toledo, Ohio on Sunday, December 18, 2022, from 2:00 p.m. until 8:00 p.m. where funeral services will begin at 7:00 p.m.

Hazel F. LeeMay 5, 1930-November 22, 2021Hazel Florence Webb was born in Los Angeles to Walter J. Webb (1894-1989) and Jessie A. (Anstiss) Webb (1898-1973). She passed away in Portland, Oregon.Just before her fourth birthday, Hazel’s parents negotiated a sight-unseen property swap with folks in Mosier, Oregon. Soon after, the family relocated to the small town in the Columbia River Gorge. The Webb family lived in several places in Mosier, most famously the big yellow house on 4th Ave., with 54 steep steps leading to the front door. Hazel cherished her childhood in Mosier. She attended Mosier grade school and high school.During her senior year, Hazel met the love of her life, Odell F. Lee, from Hood River. They married on June 19, 1948, shortly after Hazel’s graduation. Odell and Hazel made their first home together in Veneta, Oregon. With Odell’s carpentry skills and Hazel’s creative eye, they refurbished a small structure into a cozy home where they lived for several years. In May 1950, son Gary was born, joined by another son, Steven, in August 1951. After Veneta, Hazel and Odell moved to Portland, living first on SE Flavel Street, then on NE Wasco Street. In February 1956, son Robert was born, followed by son Pat in June 1959. The Wasco Street residence was small, and with four boys, the family needed more room. In the early ‘60s, Odell made a deal to have a house moved to their Wasco Street property, greatly expanding the family’s living space. Hazel was so excited, and to the boys, it was a grand event. At this time, there were other family members living on Wasco Street as well. It was a happy place to live and raise a family. It was also not too far from Mosier, and the family traveled there often to reminisce and tell stories. After 15 or so years on Wasco Street, Hazel and Odell moved to NE 160th Street in Portland, in 1971. Hazel was still residing in this home at the time of her passing.Hazel was a woman of abundant talents and numerous accomplishments, mostly self-taught and many stemming out of necessity. She was an excellent seamstress, and sewed her boys’ school shirts, made fancy square dancing dresses, and created a beautiful wedding dress for a daughter-in-law. She made adorable dolls, stuffed toys and quilts for grandchildren. She was a phenomenal baker and cook—there were always baked goodies on hand for visitors, and her Christmas treats were legendary. Hazel was an exquisite gardener and had a natural green thumb. She tended to the loveliest roses, raised the tastiest raspberries and grew from seed all the flowers used at a son’s wedding reception. She liked to take trips to gather rocks, which she used to build walls and ponds in her beautiful yard—she could tell you where every rock came from! Hazel was a whiz at budgeting and at running a household, making every penny count and skillfully stretching resources, while maintaining a loving, nurturing home.Hazel enjoyed many things, including camping trips, doll collecting, antiquing and simply sitting in her garden, where you could usually find her on a sunny day. In retirement, Hazel and Odell built a garden railroad that was so impressive, it drew visitors from all over the world. They were even filmed for television. Most of all, Hazel enjoyed her family; they were her pride and joy. She delighted in every visit, phone call, letter and Facebook interaction.Hazel was predeceased by her parents, her husband, her brother Walter Webb, sister Gladys Roberts, and grandson Austin Lee. She is survived by her four sons Gary (Jonette), Steven (Sharon), Robert, Patrick (Melody); nine grandchildren Michele Lanter (Brandon), Justin Lee (Jenifer), Brandon Lee (Allyson), Cassandra Locke (Aaron), Stephanie Mahaffey, Carson Lee, Dallas Lee, Bryce Lee, Collin Lee; and seven great-grandchildren Chase Bross, Madeline Lanter, Alexis Lee, Aiden Lee, Gabriella Locke, Eva Locke and Isla Locke. Hazel is also survived by many nieces and nephews.Hazel was an incredible daughter, sister, wife, mother, aunt, mother-in-law, and grandmother. She was the sweetest and dearest person, loved by all, and the family misses her terribly.Arrangements are under the direction of Anderson's Tribute Center (Funerals • Receptions • Cremations) 1401 Belmont Avenue, Hood River, Oregon 97031. Visit www.AndersonsTributeCenter.com to leave a note of condolence for the family.

Aleyamma Mathew, affectionately known as Santhamma by her family and friends, was born on November 25, 1952 to the late Mr. and Mrs. Thundil Mathai Thomas, Thundyil Puthen Veedu House Thatta, Kerala. She was the eldest of her family and was lovingly raised alongside her four siblings. After completing her high school diploma in 1968, she pursued a two year diploma course in Malayalam literature to become a Malayalam teacher. God, however, had a different plan and through the advice of a local priest she left home in 1971 to enroll in a nursing school in Pushpagiri Hospital Thiruvalla, Kerala. Upon completing her nursing degree, she moved to Florida in February 1975, (at the age of 22 years,) to pursue a nursing career.   Although she was raised in the Catholic tradition, her faith was challenged by a family friend who gave her a bible and encouraged her to read the New Testament for herself. Eagerly diving into the Word of God for the next six months, she quickly realized the importance of having a personal relationship with the Lord. Without hesitation, she accepted Jesus Christ as her Lord and Savior. From then on, she dedicated her life to seeking Him and doing His will. In 1977, she was baptized and maintained regular fellowship with the local baptistBaptist church in Florida.   In 1979 she moved to New York and began sincerely praying for a husband who would support and encourage her moving forward in her walk with Christ. On August 4th, 1980 she married Abraham Mathew (Raju) from Vadasserikara, Kerala. They began their married life in Bronx, New York in January 1981. As the eldest child in both of their families, they were united in their desire and responsibility to support their siblings in immigrating to the United States.   Aleyamma and Abraham were blessed with three children, Sherry, Shawn and Sheena. They lived in New York for 18 years maintaining fellowship with believers in Bronx and Rockland County. In 1998, the family moved to Houston, Texas and lived there for 20 years. After their retirement in 2018, they moved to Dallas to be close to their children and grandchildren.  Throughout her life she was dedicated to her faith and love of the Lord. She was committed to raising her children in the ways of God and was instrumental in teaching them to love the Lord and grow in their relationship in Christ. She was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2015, and the Lord extended her life for another eight blessed years where she was able to continue to witness His goodness and faithfulness. Even during her recent struggles with her cancer recurrence, she maintained her strong faith in the Lord and knew her Savior was with her every step of the way.  On August 12, 2023, Aleyamma was promoted to glory. She is survived by her husband Abraham, her daughter Sherry and husband Subi and their children Gabriel and Evelyn, her son Shawn and his wife Ashley and children Luke, Levi and Lydia and her daughter Sheena. She is also survived by her siblings Sister Karunniya, Saramma, Jose and Sicily, along with their spouses and children. She will be remembered for her dedication to her faith and reliance on the Lord. Her family eagerly awaits the day when they will be united with her again.

KERNERSVILLE -  Jenell Rayfield Hart, 86, passed away peacefully Sunday, August 6, 2023, at her home surrounded by her family. Jenell was born on June 23, 1937 in Forsyth County to Bradley Jerome and Nell Holland Rayfield.  Jenell retired from Sara Lee and was a faithful member of Sedge Garden United Methodist Church for many years. After retirement, she shared her love for helping others by volunteering at Kernersville Medical Center as long as her health would allow. She baked wonderful cakes and loved sharing them with her family and friends. Dancing, clogging, painting, and playing the piano were among her favorite past times. Jenell’s greatest joy was spending time with her family, especially her grandchildren and great grandchildren. In addition to her parents, Jenell was preceded in death by her brother, Tommy Rayfield and his wife, Gaynell. Surviving are her husband of 62 years, John Hart, Jr.; a son, Greg Hart (wife, Julie);  a daughter, Kim Shaver (husband, Mark) ; seven grandchildren; nine great grandchildren; a sister, Linda Hooven (husband, E.W.); a brother, Don Rayfield (wife, Beverly); and many nieces and nephews. Per Jenell’s request, there will be no formal services at this time. Memorials may be made to Mountain Valley Hospice, 129 Veterans Drive, Pilot Mountain, NC 27041. Hayworth-Miller Kernersville Chapel is assisting the family.
